At the America 2050 Conference in May, thinkers and policymakers gathered to imagine what our country should look like by mid-century.
Armando Carbonell from the Lincoln Institute of Land Policy in Cambridge, Massachusetts, was one of the attendees.
And he joins us from the studios of MIT.
Hi, welcome to the program.
Pleasure to be with you, Liane.
One of the big topics that was driving discussions at the forum was the concept of America's mega-regions.
Could you first tell us what those are and then how do they help envision a new kind of infrastructure?
I'm happy to do it.
A series you've been presenting over the last month on infrastructure, by the way, I think has painted a very clear picture of what's gone wrong with our national infrastructure system.
We need a national vision and an integrated strategy, but this really has to be informed by the regional differences and a kind of bottom-up process of planning.
Mega-regions are big systems of metropolitan areas like the Northeast Corridor that stretches from Boston to Washington.
And they are the right scale for major infrastructure decision-making.
For example, for big systems like high-speed rail, which Europe and Asia are literally thousands of miles ahead of us in developing.
And so that would help us if we look to Asia and Europe and how they're dealing with their so-called mega-regions.
We could learn something from them.
These are our competitors.
In Europe, which we've studied for some time, we know that the European Union is working across national boundaries to integrate the continent.
Something we started out to do here across state lines in the early days, as your series has pointed out.
But there's been at least a 50-year gap in national planning for comprehensive infrastructure across water systems, energy systems and transportation.
You know, I would imagine that the founding fathers didn't really think about climate change as they were planning infrastructure.
How do you think climate change affects infrastructure planning today?
It's clearly making a big difference.
And I have to say, I don't think we've thought much about climate change until quite recently.
But there is a new consensus that we will be transitioning to lower carbon energy sources, and we need to begin as soon as possible.
That and higher energy prices, which we've been reacting to around the country in recent months, represent new realities.
It means we're going to have to use new criteria in making decisions about investments in automotive versus transit modes, for example.
In your op-ed piece for the Boston Globe, you recommended some broad changes in mass transit, land use, energy efficient building construction.
But you also noted how this summer some families are going to be staying closer to home rather than hitting the road in the family car.
How do you think American culture and mindset will need to adapt to a new kind of infrastructure?

And…

Well, as there is no clear winner after last night - after yesterday's voting - especially on the Democratic side, that makes the people we call superdelegates all the more crucial.
They are the elected officials and party leaders who are technically uncommitted, and they'll make up about 20 percent of the delegates at the Democratic convention this summer in Denver.
One of those superdelegates is a freshman congressman from Minnesota.
He is Tim Walz.
He's also a sergeant major in the Army National Guard.
And he joins us now.
Welcome to the program.
Thanks for having me, Madeleine.
Well, what did you think of the outcome?
Oh, it was amazing.
The word is we have no clear winner.
It's obvious that we do.
The American people have turned out in huge numbers.
As a former government teacher, the idea that one of the things that you need to do and one of your responsibilities is to participate, last night was - seemed like validation.
It was incredible.
In your home state, Barack Obama won overwhelmingly, 67 percent to Hillary Clinton's 32 percent.
Does that influence you in any way?

Well, we've said all along - and the reason that I stayed out of voicing a public opinion - that I felt that this was the citizens and the constituents of my district and state's responsibility to this.
And our take on it was, is let's just let the people make up our mind and then we will cast it accordingly with them.
So they have made up their mind, and does that mean you're going with Barack Obama?
Well, we - I said we haven't made an official announcement on it, but it has been my position all along that we would let that happen the way it did.
So I would say today it's becoming a little clearer.
So we're definitely getting there.
We'll see how things shake out.
I don't believe I have any special insight to be a superdelegate necessarily.
So we think we probably just add our voice to the way that the state went and the district went.
You know, you're up for reelection as a congressman in November.
Yes.
Does it ever get kind of backroomy, where people are making deals, saying, you know, hey, we'll come out and campaign for you if you commit to us as a superdelegate?
Well, to be quite honest, it does a little bit.
I received, you know, some support.
And I would say before he was very well know, Senator Obama was in Rochester, Minnesota with me and a lot of people came out, you know, to see both of us.
Obviously now they would come out to see him, I think.
But you know, but he's never asked and it's never been a payback on that.
But the campaigns say, you know, well, you know, you've gotten help from these people and they know these people and all that.
We've tried to say, well, thank you, but we're going to stay neutral.
And - so yeah, I think it does happen.
I think there's a sense of that.
And that's the part I think your question was very good, Madeleine, that it comes back to.
I would hate to see a backroom deal make the decision when the people are voting on this.
So I think that's why we stayed very neutral and said we would go with our district says.
You are a high school civics teacher.
Yes.
Do you think that this system is democratic, that these superdelegates may in fact determine who is the party nominee and they're not actually chosen by the people who vote?
What I would like to think of is a new geography of opportunity in America.
People are going to drive less.
They'll buy more fuel-efficient vehicles.
When it comes to time to relocate, they'll think about their needs and - I think, in general - choose more centralized opportunities.
And over time, I think we will see lifestyle changes.
And I base that on what I see happening today.
